tit.cmt: タイトルですので、カッコ内の補足は削除しました。

sen.j: 玉垣（たまがき）とは、神社・神域の周囲にめぐらされる垣のことである。
sen.e: Tamagaki is a fence around a shrine or the holly precincts of a shrine.
Tamagaki is a fence around a shrine or the holy precincts of a shrine.
Tamagaki is a fence around a shrine or shiniki (the holy precincts of a shrine).
sen.cmt: 神域 追加しました。

sen.j: 神社神道が確立され、社や拝殿や本殿が、建立され敷地（自然との境界）が明確になるにつれ、曖昧であった常世と現世の境界でもある神域がはっきりと区別されるようになった。
sen.e: As Shrine Shinto was established, Shrine, Haiden (a hall of worship) and Honden (main hall) were erected, and its premises (boundary with nature) was defined, the holly precincts of a shrine, which was supposed to be a border between Tokoyo (the perpetual country) and Utsushiyo (the actual world) but was not as clear as it should have been, came to be clearly defined.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: As Shrine Shinto was established, Shrine, Haiden (a hall of worship) and Honden (main hall) were erected, and its premises (boundary with nature) was defined, the holly precincts of a shrine, which was supposed to be a border between Tokoyo (the perpetual country) and Utsushiyo (the actual world) but was not as clear as it should have been, came to be clearly defined.

As Jinja Shinto (Shrine Shinto) was established, Shrine, Haiden (a hall of worship) and Honden (main hall) were erected, and its premises (boundary with nature) was defined, the shiniki, which was supposed to be a border between Tokoyo (the perpetual country) and Utsushiyo (the actual world) but was not as clear as it should have been, came to be clearly defined.
sen.cmt: 神社神道、神域 を追加しました。

sen.j: 続いて、神籬と磐座・磐境が結びつき、石造の垣根などに代わり、現在の神社にみられる玉垣に変わっていった。
sen.e: Then, himorogi (temporarily erected sacred space or "altar" used as a locus of worship) is combined with iwakura (dwelling place of a god, usually in reference to a large rock) or iwasaka (the area a deity sits), and the border eventually turned into Tamagaki, which can be seen in current Shrine, instead of stone-built fence.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Then, himorogi (temporarily erected sacred space or "altar" used as a locus of worship) was combined with iwakura (dwelling place of a god, usually in reference to a large rock) or iwasaka (the area a deity sits), and the border eventually turned into Tamagaki, which can be seen in current Shrine, instead of stone-built fences.

Then, himorogi (temporarily erected sacred space or "altar" used as a locus of worship) was combined with iwakura (dwelling place of a god, usually in reference to a large rock) or iwasaka (the area a deity sits), and the border eventually turned into Tamagaki, which can be seen in current Shrine, instead of stone-built fences.

sen.j: 樹木をめぐらせる柴垣が最も古い形式であると考えられる。
sen.e: Shiba-gaki fence (a brushwood fence) which is made of trees is considered to be the oldest form of Tamagaki.
Shiba-gaki fence (a brushwood fence) which is made of trees is considered to be the oldest form of Tamagaki.
Shiba-gaki fence (a brushwood fence) which is made of trees is considered to be the oldest form of Tamagaki.

sen.j: 形状は、厚板を並べた板玉垣、皮がついたままの木を用いた黒木玉垣、広く間を開ける透垣などがある。
sen.e: Tamagaki comes in a variety of forms such as ita tamagaki (board fence) which is made up of thick boards, kuroki no tamagaki (unbarked lumber fence) which uses unpeeled timber, suigaki (see-through fence) which is widely spaced.

Tamagaki comes in a variety of forms such as ita tamagaki (board fence) which is made up of thick boards, kuroki no tamagaki (unbarked lumber fence) which uses unpeeled timber, suigaki (see-through fence) which is widely spaced.

Tamagaki comes in a variety of forms such as ita tamagaki (board fence) which is made up of thick boards, kuroki no tamagaki (unbarked lumber fence) which uses unpeeled timber, suigaki (see-through fence) which is widely spaced.

sen.j: 材質は木や石、近年ではコンクリートによるものもある。
sen.e: In recent years, some Tamagaki are made of tree or stone, and others are made of cement.
In recent years, some Tamagaki are made of tree or stone, and others are made of cement.
In recent years, some Tamagaki are made of tree or stone, and others are made of cement.

sen.j: 玉垣には寄進した者の名前が刻まれることがある。
sen.e: Tamagaki may carry the name of its donator.
Tamagaki may carry the name of its donator.
Tamagaki may carry the name of its donator.

sen.j: 現在の神社神道における玉垣の在り方と意味と名称
sen.e: Nature, meaning, and name of Tamagaki in the current Shrine Shinto
Nature, meaning, and name of Tamagaki in the current Shrine Shinto
Nature, meaning, and name of Tamagaki in the current Jinja Shinto
sen.cmt: 神社神道 としました。

sen.e: Meaning and synonym
Meaning and synonym
Meaning and synonym

sen.j: 瑞垣（みずがき）、斎垣（いみがき、いかき、いがき）、神垣（かみがき）は玉垣と同様にすべて同じ意味を持つ。
sen.e: 瑞垣 (Wooden fences), 斎垣 (Imigaki, Ikaki, Igaki), and 神垣 (Kamigaki) all have the same meaning as 玉垣 (Tamagaki.)
瑞垣 (Wooden fences), 斎垣 (Imigaki, Ikaki, Igaki), and 神垣 (Kamigaki) all have the same meaning as 玉垣 (Tamagaki.)
瑞垣 (Mizugaki), 斎垣 (Imigaki, Ikaki, Igaki), and 神垣 (Kamigaki) all have the same meaning as 玉垣 (Tamagaki).

sen.j: 「玉」や「瑞」、「斎」という言葉はともに「神聖な」「美しい」という意味を持つ。
sen.e: Word '玉', '瑞', and '斎' all have the meaning of 'holly' and 'beautiful.'
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Word '玉', '瑞', and '斎' all have the meaning of 'holy' and 'beautiful.'
Word '玉', '瑞', and '斎' all have the meaning of 'holy' and 'beautiful.'

sen.j: 囲いの意味である「垣」と組み合わさって「神聖なすばらしい神の為の囲い」という意味の言葉となっている。
sen.e: Those words are combined with '垣' which has the meaning of enclosure to form a word 'holly and beautiful enclosure for the god.'
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Those words are combined with '垣' which has the meaning of enclosure to form a word 'holy and beautiful enclosure for the god.'
Those words are combined with '垣' which has the meaning of enclosure to form a word 'holy and beautiful enclosure for the god.'

sen.j: 重複の囲いの場合の意味と同義語
sen.e: Meaning and synonym in case of overlapping enclosure
Meaning and synonym in case of overlapping enclosure
Meaning and synonym in case of overlapping enclosure

sen.j: 玉垣は複数めぐらすことがある。
sen.e: Multiple layers of tamagaki may be created.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Multiple layers of tamagaki may be created.
Multiple layers of tamagaki may be created.

sen.j: 一般には一番内側のものを瑞垣（みずがき）、それ以外のものを玉垣、あるいは荒垣、板垣などと呼ばれる。
sen.e: In generally, the innermost layer is called wooden fence, and other layers are referred to as Aragaki or Itagaki.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In general, the innermost layer is called wooden a fence, and other layers are referred to as Aragaki or Itagaki.
In general, the innermost layer is called Mizugaki, and other layers are referred to as Aragaki or Itagaki.
sen.cmt: wooden a fence →Mizugaki としました。

sen.j: これらの名称が混用されている場合もある。
sen.e: These names may be used together.
These names may be used together.
These names may be used together.

sen.j: 伊勢神宮内宮の御正殿（ごしょうでん）の周囲には四重に垣がめぐらされている。
sen.e: Goshoden (main sanctuary) of the Inner Shrine of Ise is surrounded by four layers of fence.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Goshoden (main sanctuary) of the Inner Shrine of Ise is surrounded by four layers of fence.
Goshoden (main sanctuary) of the Inner Shrine of Ise is surrounded by four layers of fence.

sen.j: 内側から順に、瑞垣、内玉垣（うちたまがき）、外玉垣（そとたまがき）、板垣と呼んでいる。
sen.e: Starting from the most innermost fence, those fences are called wooden fence, Uchi-tamagaki (inner fence), Soto-tamagaki (outer fence), and Itagaki respectably.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Starting from the most innermost fence, those fences are called wooden fence, Uchi-tamagaki (inner fence), Soto-tamagaki (outer fence), and Itagaki respectably.
Starting from the most innermost fence, those fences are called Mizugaki, Uchi-tamagaki (inner fence), Soto-tamagaki (outer fence), and Itagaki respectably.
sen.cmt: wooden a fence →Mizugaki としました。
